*https://www.arduino.cc :{{WPLink|Arduino}} {{See also|List of Single-board microcontrollers}} :{{WPLink|Comparison_of_single-board_microcontrollers}} :{{WPLink|List_of_Arduino_boards_and_compatible_systems}} ===Arduino=== {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding="3px" style="border: 1px solid black; border-spacing: 0px; width: 100%; text-align:center;" ! Genuino
MKR1000 | [[Arduino]] | [[Atmel]] ATSAMW25
SAMD21 MCU
32bit [[ARM]]
(Cortex-M0+),
WINC1500
802.11b/g/n,
and ECC508
crypto device | 48MHz | minimal | 61.5 × 25 mm | USB | | 3.3 V | 256 | No | 32 | 8 | 12 | 7 (1) | [http://makezine.com/2016/04/02/arduino-mkr1000-project-platform/ Announced]: April 2, 2016 | |- ! Arduino 101 https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/ArduinoBoard101
Genuino | [[Arduino]] | ''[[Intel]] Curie'' module
two tiny cores,
an x86 [[Intel]]
(Quark SE)
and an ARC | 32MHz | Arduino / Genuino | 68.6 × 53.4 mm | USB | | 3.3 V | 196 | | 24 | 14 | 4 | 6 | October 16, 2015 | Contains six-axis accelerometer, gyroscope and bluetooth |- ! Arduino Zero https://arduino.cc/en/Main/ArduinoBoardZero | [[Arduino]] | [[Atmel]] ATSAMD21
G18A | 48MHz | Arduino | 68.6 × 53.3 mm | USB | Native & EDBG Debug | 3.3 V | 256 | 0 to 16Kb emulation | 32 | 14 | 12 | 6 | Released: June 15, 2015 https://blog.arduino.cc/2015/06/15/arduino-zero-now-available-for-purchase/
Announced: May 15, 2014 https://blog.arduino.cc/2014/05/15/meet-arduino-zero/ Listed on some vendors list Mar, 2015 | Beta testing since Aug 1, 2014 https://blog.arduino.cc/2014/08/01/20-arduino-zero-dev-edition-available-for-beta-testing-join-us/ |- ! Arduino Due | [[Arduino]] | [[Atmel]]
ATSAM3X8E [[ARM]]
(Cortex-M3) | 84MHz | Mega | {{convert|4|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | 16U2 + native host | 3.3 V | 512 | 0 | 96 | 54 | 12 | 12 (2) | October 22, 2012 | The first Arduino board based on an ARM Processor. Features 2 channel 12-bit DAC, 84MHz clock frequency, 32-bit architecture, 512KB Flash and 96KB SRAM. Unlike most Arduino boards, it operates on 3.3V and is not 5V tolerant. |- ! [[Arduino Yún]] https://arduino.cc/en/Main/ArduinoBoardYun
[[Arduino Yún Rev 2]] | [[Arduino]]
.
''[[SeeedStudio]]'' | Atmega32U4
[[Atheros]] AR9331 | 16MHz
.
400MHz | Arduino | {{convert|2.7|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | | 5 V | 32 kB
.
16 MB | 1 kB,
0 kB | 2.5 kB
.
64 MB | 14 | 6 | 12 | September 10, 2013 https://blog.arduino.cc/2013/08/21/updating-about-arduino-yun-and-arduino-robot/ | Arduino Yún is the combination of a classic Arduino Leonardo (based on the ''Atmega32U4'' processor) with a Wi-Fi SoC running Linino, a [[MIPS]] GNU/Linux based on OpenWrt. |- ! Arduino Leonardo | Arduino | Atmega32U4 | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|2.7|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | 32U4 | 5 V | 32 | 1 | 2.5 | 20 | 7 | 12 | July 23, 2012 | [[File:Arduino_Leonardo.jpg|alt=Arduino Leonardo|center|200px|frameless]]
The Leonardo uses the Atmega32U4 processor, which has a USB controller built-in, eliminating one chip as compared to previous Arduinos. |- ! Arduino Uno | Arduino | ATmega328P | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|2.7|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | 8U2 (Rev1&2) /
16U2 (Rev3) | 5 V | 32 | 1 | 2 | 14 | 6 | 6 | September 24, 2010 | [[File:Arduino-uno-perspective-whitw.jpg|alt=Arduino Uno|center|300px|frameless]]
This uses the same ATmega328 as late-model Duemilanove, but whereas the Duemilanove used an FTDI chip for USB, the Uno uses an ATmega16U2 (ATmega8U2 before rev3) programmed as a serial converter. |- ! Arduino Uno WiFi rev2 {{Cite web |url=https://store.arduino.cc/usa/arduino-uno-wifi-rev2 |title=ARDUINO UNO WiFi REV2 |website=store.arduino.cc|access-date=2018-12-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181218054443/https://store.arduino.cc/usa/arduino-uno-wifi-rev2|archive-date=2018-12-18}} | Arduino | ATmega4809
Nina-W132 Wi-Fi module from u-blox, ECC608 crypto device | 16MHz | Arduino / Genuino | 68.6 mm x 53.4 mm
2.7 in x 2.1 in | USB | 32U4 | 5 V | 48 | 0.25 | 6 | 14 | 5 | 6 | [https://blog.arduino.cc/2018/05/17/say-hello-to-the-next-generation-of-arduino-boards/ Announced] May 17, 2018 | Contains six-axis accelerometer, gyroscope the NINA/esp32 module supports WiFi and support Bluetooth as Beta feature {{Cite web|url=https://forum.arduino.cc/index.php?topic=579306.0|title=Firmware Update 1.2.1 - available now, with BLE mode|website=forum.arduino.cc|access-date=2018-12-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181218054550/https://forum.arduino.cc/index.php?topic=579306.0|archive-date=2018-12-18|url-status=live}} |- ! Arduino Mega 2560 | Arduino | ATmega2560 | 16MHz | Mega | {{convert|4|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | 8U2 (Rev1&2) /
16U2 (Rev3) | 5 V | 256 | 4 | 8 | 54 | 15 | 16 | September 24, 2010 | [[File:Arduino_Mega2560.jpg|alt=Arduino Mega2560|center|200px|frameless]]
Total memory of 256kB. Uses the ATmega16U2 (ATmega8U2 before Rev3) USB chip. Most shields that were designed for the Duemilanove, Diecimila, or Uno will fit, but a few shields will not fit because of interference with the extra pins. |- ! Arduino Ethernet | Arduino | ATmega328 | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|2.7|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | Ethernet Serial interface | Wiznet Ethernet | 5 V | 32 | 1 | 2 | 14 | 4 | 6 | July 13, 2011 | [[File:Arduino_Ethernet_Board.jpg|alt=Arduino Ethernet|center|250px|frameless]]
Based on the same WIZnet W5100 chip as the Arduino Ethernet Shield. A serial interface is provided for programming, but no USB interface. Late versions of this board support PoE. |- ! Arduino Fio | Arduino | ATmega328P | 8MHz | minimal | {{convert|2.6|x|1.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | XBee Serial | | 3.3 V | 32 | 1 | 2 | 14 | 6 | 8 | March 18, 2010 | [[File:Arduino_Fio.jpg|alt=Arduino Fio|center|100px|frameless]]
Includes XBee socket on bottom of board. |- ! Arduino Nano | Arduino | ATmega328
(ATmega168 before v3.0 ) | 16MHz | minimal | {{convert|1.7|x|0.7|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | FTDI FT232R | 5 V | 16/32 | 0.5/1 | 1/2 | 14 | 6 | 8 | May 15, 2008 | [[File:Arduino_Nano.jpg|alt=Arduino Nano|center|100px|frameless]]
This small USB-powered version of the Arduino uses a surface-mounted processor. |- ! Arduino LilyPad | Arduino | ATmega168V or ATmega328V | 8MHz | wearable | {{convert|2|in|mm||abbr=on|disp=x||0}} | | | 2.7-5.5 V | 16 | 0.5 | 1 | 14 | 6 | 6 | October 17, 2007 | [[File:Flexible_Lilypad_Arduino.jpg|alt=LilyPad Arduino|center|200px|frameless]]
This minimalist design is for wearable applications. |- ! Arduino Pro [https://arduino.cc/en/Main/ArduinoBoardPro arduino.cc] | Arduino | ATmega168 or ATmega328 | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|2.0|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | UART, Serial, I2C (TWI), SPI | FTDI | 5 V or 3.3 V | 16/32 | 0.5/1 | 1/2 | 14 | 6 | 6 | | [[File:Arduino_Pro.jpg|alt=Arduino Pro|center|200px|frameless]]
Designed and manufactured by ''SparkFun Electronics'' for use in semi-permanent installations. |- ! Arduino Mega ADK | Arduino | ATmega2560 | 16MHz | Mega | {{convert|4|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | | 8U2
MAX3421E USB Host | 5 V | 256 | 4 | 8 | 54 | 14 | 16 | July 13, 2011 | |- ! Arduino Esplora | Arduino | Atmega32U4 | 16MHz | | {{convert|6.5|x|2.4|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | | 32U4 | 5 V | 32 | 1 | 2.5 | | | | December 10, 2012 | Analog joystick, four buttons, several sensors, 2 Tinker Kit inputs and 2 outputs, LCD connector |- ! Arduino Micro | Arduino | ATmega32U4 | 16MHz | Mini | {{convert|0.7|x|1.9|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | | | 5 V | 32 | 1 | 2.5 | 20 | 7 | 12 | November 8, 2012 | [[File:Arduino_Micro.jpg|alt=Arduino Micro|center|200px|frameless]]
This Arduino was co-designed by ''Adafruit''. |- ! Arduino Pro Mini | Arduino | ATmega328 | 8MHz (3.3V) /
16MHz (5V) | Mini | {{convert|0.7|x|1.3|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | Six pin serial header | | 3.3 V / 5 V | 32 | 1 | 2 | 14 | 6 | 6 | | Designed and manufactured by ''SparkFun Electronics''. |- ! Arduino Serial | Arduino | ATmega8 | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|3.2|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | DE-9 serial connection | native | | | | | | | | | [[File:Arduino316.jpg|alt=Arduino Serial|center|200px|frameless]]
The first board labelled "Arduino". |- ! Arduino USB | Arduino | ATmega8 | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|3.2|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | FTDI FT232BM | | | | | | | | | [[File:A_hand-soldered_Arduino.jpg|center|200px|frameless|Arduino USB v2.0]]
Changed: USB replaces RS-232 interface, Improved: Arduino can be powered from host. |- ! Arduino Extreme | Arduino | ATmega8 | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|3.2|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | | | | | | | | | | The Arduino Extreme uses many more surface mount components than previous USB Arduino boards and comes with female pin headers. |- ! Arduino NG
(''Nuova Generazione'') | Arduino | ATmega8 | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|3.2|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | FTDI FT232RL | | | | | | | | | [[File:Arduino_top-1.jpg|alt=Arduino NG|center|200px|frameless]]
Improved: FT232BM has been replaced by FT232RL to require fewer external components, LED on pin 13 added. |- ! Arduino NG plus | Arduino | ATmega168 | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|3.2|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | | | | | | | | | | |- ! Arduino BT
(''Bluetooth'') | Arduino | ATmega168
ATmega328 | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|3.2|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | Bluetooth | BlueGiga WT11 Bluetooth | 5 V | 32 | 1 | 2 | 14 | 4 | 6 | October 22, 2007 | [[File:Arduino_BT.jpg|alt=Arduino BT|center|200px|frameless]]
Similar to the Arduino NG, this has a Bluetooth module rather than a serial interface. Programming is carried out via Bluetooth. |- ! Arduino Diecimila | Arduino | ATmega168
(DIP-28) | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|2.7|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | FTDI | 5 V | 16 | 0.5 | 1 | 14 | 6 | 6 | October 22, 2007 | [[File:Flamingo_Arduino.jpg|alt=Arduino Diecimila|center|200px|frameless]]
Improved: Host is able to reset the Arduino, pin headers for reset and 3.3V, low dropout voltage regulator allows lower voltage on external power source. |- ! Arduino Duemilanove
(''2009'') | Arduino | ATmega168, ATmega328P
(ATmega328 for newer version) | 16MHz | Arduino | {{convert|2.7|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | FTDI | 5 V | 16/32 | 0.5/1 | 1/2 | 14 | 6 | 6 | October 19, 2008 | [[File:Limited-edition_orange_Arduino_Duemilanove.jpg|alt=Arduino Duemilanove, an early production example in orange |center|200px|frameless]]
Improved: automatically switching between USB and external power, eliminating jumper. |- ! Arduino Mega | Arduino | ATmega1280 | 16MHz | Mega | {{convert|4|x|2.1|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | USB | FTDI | 5 V | 128 | 4 | 8 | 54 | 14 | 16 | March 26, 2009 | [[File:Arduino_Mega_2.jpg|alt=Arduino Mega|center|250px|frameless]]
Uses a surface-mounted ATmega1280 for additional I/O and memory. |- ! Arduino Mini | Arduino | ATmega168
(Pro uses ATMega328) | 8MHz (3.3V)/
16MHz (5V) | | {{convert|0.7|x|1.3|in|abbr=on|disp=x|mm|||1}} | | | 5 | 16 | 0.5 | 1 | 14 | 6 | 6 | August 23, 2008 | [[File:Arduino_Mini.jpg|alt=Arduino Mini|center|100px|frameless]]
This miniature version of the Arduino uses a surface-mounted processor. |- |} == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |url = http://www.atmel.com/devices/ATSAMD21G18.aspx |title = ATSAMD21G18;
